body: LBR04: S. Joshua  Swamidass - Marginal Cost of Discovery: An Economic Alternative to False Discovery Rate

comments.body: Developed in the process of high-throughput screening at the Broad Institute.300,000 compunds are screened (somehow) to produce a ranked list, a distribution across a response variable.
Find threshold to verify the top n compounds on the list.
How many hits should be sent to confirmatory experiments?
Most commonly, people simply guess, often arbitrary and unfair. FDR is typically preferred but it's argued that  it's just as arbitrary.
Two flaws of FDR: Need to pick a FDR cutoff and FDR assumes that everything different than the negative controls is interesting, often not the case in the compound testing.
Key question: What is the most profitable number of confirmed activities to produce? Think supply-demand curves.
Determine the supply cost (how many positive are produced) and the demand curve by the cost of finding one more active compound.
Results (it works, numbers).
(Unpublished work in scaffold disovery)
Q: Assumptions on distributions. A: Less assumptions than FDR. Only assumption is that there is some signal in the original test.
Q: Power comes from option to back to the screen. Not possible easily in microarray experiments. A: Testing happens in MA analysis and recommends to use similar verifying settings there, too.
Q: How find the demand curve? A. Should only be controlled by the costs (funding, importance). Does not need explicitly modeled.
Main improvement is to tie follow up experiments to real costs rather than some rather abstract statistic.

# Moving the LBR track to 201; constantly been packed before

body: LBR03: Erik  Larsson - mRNA half-life affects susceptibility to RNAi

comments.body: From Chris Sanders lab in Sloan-Kettering. Small RNAs  regulate  gene expression. Argument of this talk: Low degradation rate will result in high changes, high degradation rates will lead to low changes after RNAi.
not all about the site - some transcripts "not-targetable" - Kreuger et al oligonucleotides 2007
siRNA rules have been designed focussing on the target site so far.
Theoretical model  for high turnover mRNAs. More difficult to perturb. depends on pre-existing turnover and independent of transcription rate
mRNA half life varies between minutes and days. Will they respond differently to RNAi?
Validation in a simple reporter system, stabilization via (AUUU)n extension..

Evaluation in HeLa cells. siRNA targeting high-turnover transcripts is weak. Results not large but significant. Sequence property will explain more. Improved correlation with multiple siRNAs for the same gene.
Nice talk, clear hypothesis and conclusion.

body: Keynote: Steven Brenner - Ultraconserved nonsense: gene regulation by splicing & RNA surveillance

comments.body: ISMB2010 just kicked off
Prof Søren Brunak introducing Steven Brenner, ISCB overton prize winner
Brenner contributed to many fields in bioinformations, starting in structureal biology ober RNA to metagenomics.
A short biography, summarizing Soren Brunaks kind introduction http://compbio.berkeley.edu/people...
The morphology of steves paper: http://www.improbable.com/airchiv...
Intro: The ultraconservative (as seen from Berkely) and nonsense (as found in Through the Looking Glass
The jabberwocky poem does have meanings and is elegantly crafted.
Generally, nonsens in biology is bad.
Nonsense is generally bad, even in a codon
Truncated proteins might interfere with physiological function (dominant negative). The cell removes such transcripts through nonsense-mediated decay (NMD).
Good example for NMD: Sox10
Mutations early in the gene leads to less severe phenotypes than later ones
NMD is an mRNA surveillance system
NMD important to development of the immunesystem and cleans up other transcriptional errors.
We do not know how NMD works outside the mammals.
The mechanism involves the splicing machinery. If a  stop is found wwithin 50nt upstream of the exon junction complex, it is removed..
50 nucleotide rule - translated normally or degraded by NMD
brilliant nytimes article title - surviving on low number of genes
splicing can introduce PTC - premature termination codon
AS as mechanism to introduce PTCs - can lead to unproductive splicing
these isoforms often have PTC
Humans have fewer genes but better genes, due to AS.
Are PTC splice forms funcitonal?
Many PTC mRNAs are noise
analgous mechanism to shrinter: http://www.geeky-gadgets.com/cool-ga...
Humans have fewer genes but better genes, due to AS.
Related reference: http://compbio.berkeley.edu/people...
Alt splicing can yield isoforms differentially subjected to NMD
SR protein - 11 in human which are serine and arginine rich
SR proteins have premature stop codons.
SR genes has mRNAs with premature termination codons
AS of PTC isoforms is mechanism for autoregulation of proteins
NMD has a large effect on isoform abundance
NMD has impact on isoform abundance - example of NMD clearing the major isoform
minor isoforms are only shared 25% of time - modrek and lee 2003
Not just anecdotal stories, splice patterns are conserved in mouse, implying functional significance.
(Unpulbished work)
All the SR proteins are talking to each other
SR proteins 'compensate' for each other via coupling via AS and NMD
SR genes have ultraconversed elements .. Bejerano et al 2004 Science 304: 1321
Most ultraconserved regions are in intergenic regions, the regions in SR within genes.
question of why conserved - not protein coding, no obvious significant RNA secondary structure
No proteins are produced from these genes.
The reason why SR sequences are highly conserved - most of the seq are not protein coding,
no repetitive elements
why conserved part 2 - no overrepresentation of binding / regulatory elements
No simple explanations e.g. from miRNA binding etc.
no similarity elsewhere in genome except retropseudogenes
analysis on origin of unproductive splicing
No sequence similarity between the conserved elements. Seems to have been introduced mutliple times.
mouse and human SRp55 conserved but changing
working on chordate SR proteins
here intron and exon structure is more informative
at this point - he has requested no further blogging - unpublished work
no blog slides may be over
# Looks like interesting work.
wonderful talk
Tells a (hard to blog) story about the successful treatment of collaborator with novel treatment based on genotyping.
Wow - what a conclusion! Fantatic talk...
# Certainly great work. The talk was nice too, and he only bitched at other reseachers in person once, another step up.
"Ultraconversed elements in SR genes ONLY show  similarity to retropseudogenes" - what does this mean? Any takers?

body: Keynote: Susan Lindquist - Protein Folding and Environmental Stress REDRAW the Relationship between Genotype and Phenotype

comments.body: Inherited Environmentally acquired traits - lamarck wasn't so insane
Protein folding - environment is very important ... showed videos
experiments in heat shock tolerance -initial small shock allowed for survival -hsp proteins are made in massive amounts - role in protein folding
Hsp90 a special chaperone.
in excess in cell - acts as homeostasis buffer
Hsp90 a special chaperone.
hsp70 helps early stage folding and works with a number of proteins, but not hsp90.
HSP 90 a special chaperone ... because very abundant, it induced by two folds, it has extra folding capability .... acts as a buffer
Signal transduction networks & HSP90 ...  Hanahan and Weinberg, cell 2000
showed signal transduction network involved by hsp90. It seems pretty spread.
hsp90's function is found by an accident.
Hsp90 mutations in fruit flies leads to death of flies
some mutated fruit flies survived revealed that hidden genetic variant. Hsp90 does not destabilize development.
raise fly at high temperature can reduce the amount hsp90 level, easier than did it in a genetic way
Hsp90 a special chaperone.
acts as a capacitor for some variation .... it also acts as a potentiator for other variation
both fly and arabidopsis experiments show that hsp90 acts a buffer for variations.
hsp90 can complex with inactive hormone receptors and oncogenic kinases
hsp90 helps mutated kinase, which lost the ability to inhibit itself.
same thing happened in human diseases.
so hsp90 inhibitor can be used for a drug.
there are a few fungi drugs available clinically
remove level hsp90 buffer level completely removed the drug resistance evolution
Raise temperature again eliminated the drug resistant development. Should the patient be put in fever stage.
talked about some unpublished data
Where is the bioinformatics ?
when added hsp90 inhibitor, some traits disappeared but some showed up
ame, people who analyzed the data, :-)
it should be a huge work to make genotype to phenotype map
the polymorphism in NFS1 that required for tRNA modifications caused the phenotype charge
polymorphisms in 3' UTR of HNI1 is also affected by hsp90, but not directly instead through the proteins binding to that region.
has Hsp90 left an imprint on genomes that exist today?
hsp90 affects polymorphisms throughout the genome even non-coding, in combinatorial way
it is benefit to human is the big reason to continue the research.
yeast prions - genetic element based on protein conformation
prion also switches on  with environmental stress
prion has similar behavior of hsp90. It generates new phenotypes.

body: SS2: Chromatin and Gene Regulation II: Epigenomics

comments.body: Manolis Kellis: Systems level view of transcription. Regulatory networks across species using conservation. Effects on top of nucleosome positioning:  The histone code leads to a multitude of combinations.
[...] Signatures of transcription factor binding and nucleosomes in different cell lines. Dips in chromatin signal hints TF sites, associated with conservation. Many cell type specific dips.
William Stafford Noble: Segmentation for chromatin states.Very general talk with lots of colorful plots and no formula (regrettably if you ask me).
Chris Bock:Biomarker development from epigenomics
Epigenetic aberrations that lead to cancer could be reversed, a handful examples are in the clinic.
Epigenetic biomarkers are detectable earlier than genetic changes and possibly from blood.
Showcase example SEPT9 promoter methylation (diagnostic). MGMT promoter methylation as therapy selection. LINE repeat meth to monitor effect of demeth drugs.

Search for biomarkers promising. Bioinformatics challenge in distinguishing tissues, not mechanistic inferences. A variety of technologies exist. Four selected for this studies: MeDIP, MethylCap, RRBS (sequencing based, bisulfite) and Infimium (apapted microarray, bisulfite).
Benchmarking: Good agreement between bisulfite method. Enrichment methods display sequence biases with low correlations. Repeats show spurious hits.
Linear models can correct  for sequence biases.
Differentially methylated regions detection using Fisher's exact test.
Software available (Epigraph) http://epigraph.mpi-inf.mpg.de/WebGRAP... etc.
Xiaole Shirly Liu: Inferring in vivo transcription factor binding from histone mark dynamics
Dependency on availability of antibodies for ChIP experiments.
Re-analysis of data of histone modification at nucleosomal position.
Importance of transcription factor binding vs histone mod.
Use H3K4mew2 dynamics to infer transcription factor binding sites. (http://www.nature.com/ng...)
TFs in gut differentiation.New motifs detected. Work in progress.

body: PT31: Adrian V. - VARiD: A Variation Detection Framework for Colorspace and Letterspace platforms

comments.body: Color space allowing to distinguish SNPs from sequencing errors.
HMM based, states map to dinucleotides and therefore overlap.
Colors are not modeled, insufficient data to deduce the sequence.
Application of Forward-Backward algorithm gives distribution at each position.
Extension to indels and heterogeneous SNPs. Add several gap characters (by color), increasing to 1600 states. Not so problematic due to sparse transition probabilities.
Support quality values and variable error rates for emissions.
Performance similar to individual color space or letter space data. Major improvements with mixed data.

body: LBR11: Mark  Wass - Towards the prediction of protein interaction partners using physical docking

comments.body: 1-10% of protein-protein interactions have been identified. Need for prediction.
Most methods for prediction are genomic or sequence based but not structure based.

Protein docking: finding and scoring interaction poses between two proteins. Hard problem to distinguish interactors from non-interactors. Use of the Weng benchmark set of 65 complexes. Measure distribution of scores.
Build decoy set and assume they are not interacting with the benchmark set. Some examples show separation but fails for several. 36 complexes outperform rank better than the 80%.
Where on the interactors are docking solutions generated? Some AA are involved more frequently than others.
Still way to go before predictions are possible but a signal is present.

The problem with methods that try to optimize discrimination between natives and a set of decoys is that they usually find problems in the docking software / energy function. I.e. you'll discover that decoys have very weird electrostatics distribution etc... A good set of non-interactors would be key to develop this field further

scoring is indeed a bottleneck in docking. however there is a signal found in this work, it can be very helpful both for docking and prediction of interactions to understand where this signal comes from.

body: HL21: Rachel Kolodny - FragBag: representing protein structures as 'bags-of-fragments' allows efficient exploration of protein structure space.

comments.body: Published paper here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...
Protein structure search - a computationally hard problem
Looking for similar structures that are not easily found using SCOP and CATH.
1st line tool - structural alignments. However, these are expensive computationally, not feasable for full PDB. Alternative - filter methods that can look at full-size PDB.

disclaimer of un-objectivity - I'm a co-author on related paper with Rachel (Kosloff & Kolodny, Proteins 2008) that she just mentioned as motivation to look at the whole PDB rather than a non-redundant subset.
FragBag = new filter method, based on library of fragments
order of fragments in structure is not considered (similar to how Google indexes web pages). You lose information but gain speed dramatically. Worked for Google, so might work for structures.
Uses SAS score as similarity measure = RMSD*100/length
Uses SAS to find best of six different structure alignment methods as gold standard.
Near neighbors: SAS <= 5A
checks if FragBag finds nearest neighbors found by gold standard. analysis with ROC curves.

rank of methods by area under ROC curve: sequence alignment is worse (as expected) structural alignments range from > 0.7 to 0.9. FragBag does as well as CE etc., even though it's a lot less expensive in computational resources.
FragBag also finds pairs of structures with same CATH classification
Additional features: enables to query PDB with combination of non-continuous sub-structures
Also enables to visualize protein structure space (shows rotating 3D projection of 30,000 structures) - you get the (known) separation of structures classes (alpha+beta, alpha, beta, alpha/beta)
superimposes SCOP folds on this picture, visualizes co-localization of these folds.
answer to Q: Can search entire PDB on laptop very quickly.

body: HL20: Smita Agrawal - Computational Models of the Notch Network Elucidate Mechanisms of Context-dependent Signaling

comments.body: Presentation of a PLoS CB publication. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc...
Differential equation modeling of various aspects of Notch signaling, incl. binding, localization, translation, transcription. First order models for formation of biomolecules.
Bistability in the Notch-Hes1 network. The switching points can be determined, undergoes hysteresis.
Provides the cell with noise filtering.
Response to a transient Delta signal. Signal can be short and high or continuous to switch the response on.
Sensitivity of to model parameters. Loss of bistability turns oncogenes on.
Some parameters are not critical. Key parameter is repressive constant of Hes1. Systems start oscillating at some point. Bridged by a brief monostable state.
Nice bridge between the biological and a complex model, well presented.

body: Keynote: Svante Pääbo - Analyses of Pleistocene Genomes

comments.body: This will probably be a very interesting talk. Just can't wait.
Not just interesting, but most likely great. Svante is a fantastic speaker

If you’re interested in human history, the genome is a great source of information.  To reconstruct history, we compare sequences of people (and other species) living today.  We use models of how DNA changes over time to understand the differences that exist today.
This is an indirect way to study history, because we are reconstructing from the present what we think has happened in the past.
specimens are highly contaminated, ....
mtDNA - advantage of many copies per cell
original work from 1984 on egyptian mummy - http://www.sciencedirect.com/science...
Replacement (out of africa theory) vs assimilation  (i.e. geneflow from modern humans)
mtDNA is extracted from a specimen from neanderthal
Started with the original neanderthal specimen
The variation in human population origins before the split (as measured by mtDNA) of modern and neanderthals
extract dna from skull, skip PCR and directly sequence
only 3.5% actually from neanderthal genome
Average length 50 nucleotides
Vindija Cave, Croatia  .... 3 bones
only about 3.5% of dna came from human
3 billion fragments - again most from bacteria
most dna is bacterial contaminants
avg genome cover is 1.5X
most DNA extracted is female look at Y chrom % as contaminant
Three females samples (and therefore Y chromosome contamination can be used to calculate noise). Total risk is below 1% risk of contaimination
at any particular position - 1% chance contamination (broken down by source - 3 measures)
consistant nucleotide chemical changes at 5' and 3' ends
try to correct by alignments to human and chimpanzee genomes
Details on bioinformatics and alignment issues (led by Ed Green) can be found in Science paper - http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi...
55% chance of seeing a position covered by at least 1 read

typical european (French) 8% divergence to human reference compared with 12% in neanderthal

detection of selective sweeps - look for snps in human, chimps, neanderthals - r egions where neanderthal looks all ancestral.

body: Keynote: Chris Sander - Systems Biology of Cancer Cells

comments.body: An interview with Chris Sander ... http://www.mskcc.org/mskcc...
Kabsch and Sander paper - over 6000 citations - http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...
Note the subliminal message in the announcement slide
Prediction by transparency - no computation necessary story
Awards should be shared: People working with Chris includes: Burkhard Rost, Alfonso Valencia, Liisa Holm and many more
Announcement of unpublished and new work. A good trend at this ISMB.
Cancer genome atlas: TCGA
Mapping of molecular alterations (cpy number variation) to 200 glioblastoma samples. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc...
Difference between patients is huge
extract network, find relevant modules.
illustration of netbox algorithm
When grouping mutations into  pathways up to 85% of GBM have a muation in the most important pathways, while individual genes are down to a few %
Each oncogene may have relatively low frequency across patients; but when you group genes across pathways, a pathway may explain a large fraction of patients with a given type of cancer.
"Network pharmacology"
can see a change in pathway activation between primary tumor and mets
Dominant alterations changes between cancer types and states.
GBM: copy number is rare (and noisier) Ovarian: more regular and higher
profiles of copy numbre variations differ between types of cancers

Metastatic tumor samples have more copy number changes than primary tumors.  Not surprising.  But maybe primary samples with more copy number changes than others are more likely to metastasize?  Generally, better outcome with fewer somatic copy number changes.
BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations convey germline inherited cancer risk
These genes act in the homologous repair pathway.  Half of all patients have mutations in some homologous repair pathway gene.
and more generally, homologous repair genes are altered in > 50% of ovarian cancer
Tumor suppressor genes can be inactivated in various ways:  germline mutation, somatic mutation, epigenetic silencing, etc.
There are drugs under development that might work particularly well in patients with defects in this particular pathway.
Cancer genomics portal:  www.cbio.mskcc.org/cancergenomics
mutationassessor.org
Topic shift:  now, perturbation cell biology.  "and belief propagation".  (eh?)
Perturbation Cell Biology
In recent past, says Chris, you make a few perturbations:  overexpress or knock down a gene; inhibit with a compound, etc.
use network inference algorithms
goal = predictive models for therapy
with only 200 datapoints -> derive validated (known) pathways
Prediction of networks does not scale to larger networks
Large data generation with the number of pertubation > than proteins.
Still prohibitively large number of networks even for small number of nodes.
Use statistical physics methods to tackle combinatorial explosion of possible networks.
Inference using belief propagation known from statistical physics.
Ah, here is where "belief" comes in. Network inference using belief propagation. Reference Riccardo Zecchina et al. http://users.ictp.it/~zecchi...
Instead of going through all the models that are possible, you derive statistical properties across a set of good models for each of the Wij weights in the model.
This is sort of like partition functions in statistical physics
evolving work on Wij (transition from Nelander et al 2008- http://www.nature.com/msb...)
Cavity approach - optimize locally on global background iteratively cover all local cavities
Mm, this is rather opaque to me.
"Let me give you some intuition about how this all works."  Yes, I'd like that.
Nice results on toy experiment - constraints from 10 experiments with 5 interactions (the nodes W in factor graph).
Almost looks too good
after step 1 - generation of probability distributions then step 2- decimation

So you have a probability distribution for each Wij, which represents the interaction between element i and element j.  I'm not really getting how you "update" these probability distributions in the iterative steps.  I do understand that at the end you take the most "certain" (narrowest) distribution and fix its value (some Wij) at the most probable value, then update all the other Wij's given this fixation.  And so on.  To get your final model in a sort of greedy fashion.
And by the way, the underlying model is a simple differential equation sort of thing: change of one variable xi is a sigmoidal function of weighted (Wij) sum of all variables xj, less a decay term.
thanks for the summary bb
Mike!
Mentions bunches of other stuff in passing.  Like bioPAX: paper in press.
bioPAX is community project on pathways, ontology, and exchange format.
"no science without people; science for the people; ask good questions"
Biopax.org
Ask good questions !!!!!
Question:  Interacting network tend to be modular, with strongly-interacting subnetworks that interact weakly with each other.  ...
Chris:  Is the modular approach really useful in confronting the data?  [Is that what he said?]
Question: can you get at causal relationships?
Chris:  yes - if the network model allows you to predict correctly the result of a particular perturbation applied to a particular node, then you can simulate using that model.
Question:  with a big network, how many experiments will you need to model?

Chris: Good question.  Could use an entropy measure.  Help us figure this out.  Help us design the experiments.  It's important because of the costs of experiment.  This is going to be broadly applicable in cell biology.
bb - he said one should see if approach is useful by confronting with real data
Ah, thx
Chris gets at the difference between a model that tells a story and a model that is truly predictive.
Question: yes, but, what are the semantics of the graph?  What kinds of interaction?  Answer:  The semantics are in the mathematics of your model.
Question:  mean field approach is interesting.  Compared to Monte Carlo approach, you are assuming some decoupling.  Loss of posterior coupling between weights - is that an issue?

Chris:  If you look at a coupled system overall, the extent to which the algorithms work depends on correlations within the system.  Long-range (in terms of network distance) correlations are problematic.  There are some clever approaches to handle some of this.  Mentions non-ergotic space; deal with parts of space separately or iteratively.

body: Is there interest in a Birds of Feather session tomorrow regarding (micro) blogging?

comments.body: ... or simpy a joint luncheon?
joint luncheon sounds good.
mentioned this before but might have been lost: if ISCB has to do something to support this crucial activity: let us know!

OK, then let's meet for lunch tomorrow. Please spread the word. It'll be easiest if we meet at 12:50 at the hallway leading to the ballrooms on the 3rd floor.  Burkhard: Thanks for the support, we'll get back to you.

@Burkhard: most people that sat next to me had no idea about this room or about FF, despite the prominent slide and the links from the ISMB webpage. Perhaps if you show a screenshot before a keynote, awareness will increase?
Afraid the horrible wireless connection made (live) blogging nearly impossible for many sessions. Was going to cover the late breaking research session today from 201, but no luck.
Must have missed you. Got there a couple of minutes late and didn't see anyone.
Hmm, let's try to meet at the reception. It'll be a search in 2D space so we should find each other in finite time. I will be in room 302 for the remainder of the afternoon.
What about another projector projecting the feed, in talks by some daring presenters?

I won't be able to make the reception. My 3 ideas are: separate (secure) wireless for bloggers. Incentives (e.g. Priority for plos-cb postcard publications). Wider campaign to recruit micro bloggers before ismb.
1. projection of the feed: don't get the reason. 2. wireless 4 blog: good idea, 3. plos-cb postcard slot: will talk to phil/plos, 4. other incentives: what you want?
Reason for wireless4blog is most likely due to low speed here

It's not a bandwidth problem, I had throughputs on the MB/s. More likely, many of our computers have problems in this mixed settings with "smart" handling of receiver power etc. In Vienna, I had a clever tech guy that helped to disentangle these issues with my network card. What we (all) would really need is some sort of true hacker with proper equipment but I have no good idea how to recruit such a person.
Can bottleneck be between local server and ISP ?

body: HL40: Martin Vingron - Histone modification levels are predictive for gene expression

comments.body: See PNAS 2010 Feb 16.
Using histone modification data in Barski et al and Wang et al and one other.
Li, Carey, Workman 2007 Cell 128:707 review.  Tabulates distribution of modifications along the genes.
Some are activating; some repressing; some either.  Occur in various locations along the gene.
They want ot go from histone modification vector to transcription level.
Zhao lab data: 38 histone modifications.  Look in promoter region.
-2000 to +2000 around TSS.  Introduce a pseudocount alpha: x = log(N + alpha).
Standard linear regression.
Graph of predicted vs measured log expression values.  High correlation.  In fact, it looks bimodal.
Looked at where the information resides.  Tried using single, pair or 3 modifications and see how close can get to optimal prediction.
Most predictive modifications are H4K20me1, H3K27ac, H3K79me1, H2BK5ac
Shows a histogram of promoters with respect to CpG ratio.
Which modifications are informative depends on CpG content.  CpG rich:  H4K20me1, and to some extent H3K27ac, H2BK5ac some.  CpG-depented: H3K4me3, H3K79me1.
Predicting in other cell types.  Cui et al 2009:  ChIP-seq data for CD36+ and CD133+ T cells.  10 histone mods (H3K4me1/3, H3K27me1/3, H3K36me3, H4K20me1, H3K9me1/3, H2A.Z) + gene expression data.

Trained a model for those 10 mods on initial dataset, then tested on the new data.  Prediction still pretty accurate.  However, these cell types are quite closely related.  So looked at genes that are differentially expressed between the cells.  Even there, th eprediction is still pretty good.
H4K20me1 and H3K79me1 associated wtih elongation; H3K4me3, H3K27ac, H2BK5ac are sasociated wtih the TSS.
Summarizes:  expression and histone meodification levels are quantifiably related.  This holds across cell lines
Common prejudice: Low-CpG promoters drive tissue specific genes.

body: PT41: Steven Kelk - Phylogenetic Networks Do not Need to Be Complex: Using Fewer Reticulations to Represent Conflicting Clusters

comments.body: Many reasons to obtain conflicting trees, some have legitimate reasons (hybridization etc) which can be modeled as phylogenetic networks.
Clusters are subset of leaves, basically a hypothesis that at least one trees contain such a clade.
Clusters loose the topological information. Let's the user specify data that are trusted.
Minimize the number of reticulations, motivated by parsimony but by evolution.
Algorithm CASS attempts to produce such networks and does so well (60 slide of math not shown)
Tested on different subsets obtained from a Poaceae grass data set (PWG 2001, Smidt 2003). Comparison to Hybrindinterleave, PIRN, Galled Trees and Cluster Network.
CASS works well in practice. Integrated in Dendroscope. Running times slightly longer than competitors.

body: HL38: Kyoungjae Won - Applying histone modification information to genome-wide prediction of transcription factor binding sites

comments.body: Started with 8 histone modifications as training data, and 13 transcription factors (ChIP-seq binding data; evaluation set) and another evaluation set.  All in mouse stem cells.
Shows example Oct4, with enhancer specific binding properties - low H3K4me3 and high H3K4me1.
To train a model for Klf4: looked for high H3K4me3 with the Klf4 PSSM; at teh enhancer looked for high H3K4me1/2 and Klf4 PSSM.
His software/method is called Chromia.
Train with HMM; 3 HMMs, one for promoter binding Klf4, one for enhancer binding Klf4, and one for background.
Conservation information seems to worsen the predictions!
Used RNAi against the TF
Used a 3-state HMM, which captures the spatial pattern of histone marks
Chromia predicts locations of enhancers and promoters.  Chromia predicts nucleosome free regions.
Publication:  BMC Bioinformatics
Colleagues Wei Wang, Bing Ren, Robert Shoemaker, Iouri Chevelev
Reference for this work: http://genomebiology.com/2010...
Question about relative weight of PSSMs and histone marks in the models.

comments.body: He points out that there is work just published that is quite similar to their work - http://www.nature.com/nmeth...
integrative approach - see work in Drosophila BMC Genomics 2009 10:2220; siRNA and PPI - Genome Research 2009-19:1057-1067
key assumption - real hits will not be randomly distributed in physical interaction network - should reside in subnetworks
Ranking algorithm to compare query node with rest of nodes with known hit/non-hit status (NePhe score is then summarized)
trade-off between quality of hits and algorithm choice
Assumption that hit is not randomly distributed assumes that RNAi is hitting its Target. Results from random naming seems to validate that this assumption is reasonable.

body: HL35: Liran Carmel - A universal relationship between gene compactness and expression level in multicellular eukaryotes

comments.body: From Eugene Koonin's group: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc...
Different lengths for a gene - total transcript length, 5'UTR length, introns, etc
Expression levels are collapsed to a single value by ranking by condition/tissue into 3 category and average and round the resulting rank.
First observed in C. elegans http://www.nature.com/ng...
Found in other organisms and for several length measures and different strategies for expression.
20 nucleotides are transcribed in one second
one nucleotide needs two ATPs
Intergenic length and compactness are related.
Plants have opposite trend
Exception in plants: highly expressed genes are least compact.
No good explanation for the outlier, usually selection and genomic design are given.
New explanation: the relationship is not monotonous but peaked.
Segmented regression recovers the relationship easily.
Use of mixed gamma distributions to estimate noise and real expression level by tissue.
Selection rather than genomic design shapes the length distributions.
Q: Relation of intron length and alternative splicing. A: Probably not.
Q&A: Intron length changes more pronounced than exon lengths.
Q: Specific tissues: A. Interesting but not yet analyzed.

body: Keynote: David Altshuler - Genomic Variation and the Inherited Basis of Common Disease

comments.body: Altshuler is an expert on diabetes type II.
It is said that he is also a good dancer.
Tap, ballroom, or tango?
Slide dancing
motivation is to understand genetic basis of human diseases
Genetic basis of human diseases - important disease mechanisms and bio pathways remain unidentified
gap in knowledge of human disease biology contribute to high failure rates in drug development
Why understanding genetic mechanisms ? (1) Important mechanism remain unidentified (ii) Gaps in knowledge causes failure rate in drug development
It will be a long way to know if the two motivating hypotheses are true
one of the most research on T2D. It scaned 100k people for 10 yrs
10 years later 50% progressed to have the disease
10years of diabetic research - the out come is - 50% of people with good lifestyle improved
lifestyle has a bigger impact than Metformin

Diabetes study with 10-year follow-up of diabetes incidence and weight loss, "T2D".  Randomized into treatments:  lifestyle, metformin, placebo.  Best drug makes relatively little difference in incidence; lifestyle intervention is better than drug but still doesn't help a whole lot.
best prevention was extensive lifestyle changes (50% -> 40% incidence)
Diabetes is not only a matter of life style
success rate in current pharma industry is <5% of molecules entering the clinical trails
This is bad !!
mentions well known number of >95% failure rate of new compounds
because there are still 40% people got the disease after the lifestyle change, it seems that people do not know the course of the disease
a genetic approach - http://www2.massgeneral.org/chrg...
Genetic mapping started in 1913
genetic map came in 1913
Morgan and Sturtevant 1913
emphasizes he advocates a genetecist's approach (rather than a genomic approach)
And tells you to skip undergraduate work if you have something better to do
key attributes of genetic mapping - unbiased by prior assumptions about pathways
saturation mutagenesis reveals pathways
key attributes of genetic mapping: (1) unbiased by prior assumptions about pathways (2) saturation mutagenesis reveal pathways
many mutants -> reveals coherence of pathways
These days we have other methods that are unbiased like expression profiling, but genetic mapping has some unique characteristics relative to these (he’ll explain in a minute).
Drosophola's mutations looked initially random, years they almost all related to pathways.
bottleneck is functional determination - biochemical approaches
A lot of current knowledge can track back to genetic mapping
Botstein and Fink Science 1988 ....
A slide based on Galzier et al, Science 2002
genetic mapping of human single gene disorders ...over 15 years  Botstein paper in 1980, first genetic map in 1985 ....
It took 10 year to find maker for Huntington disease
Once you find a linked region from genetic mapping, it still takes a long time to find the specific gene responsible.
in the 1990's the idea was that common diseases were caused by rare mutations with large effects
"Chromosome shlepping" - Eic  Lander's term for the identification of a very gene in some genomic region.
It is robust to find mendelian disease but to not common diseases
another approach: population genetics - QTL approach
phenotypic variation is often continuous and may involve variation in many genes
Galton invented  regression analysis to analyze the measuring of phenotypic data (heights of parents and offspring).
The biometric unit  --- almost  nothing was Mendelian
Most traits are continuously variable

Francis Galton was a cousin of Darwin.  Darwin didn’t explain the source of variation.  Galton focused on this; he measured the heights of parents and their offspring, and found a relationship.  He invented regression analysis to draw the line.  The slope of the line is related to the inheritability of the disease.
It was studied by the cousin of Darwin, Francis Galton (1885)
phenotypic variation is often continuous ... some history ... Francis Galton (1885), Ronald Fisher (1918), Hermann Muller (1920)
This gave rise to the biometric movement – measure every living thing.  Traits were related to genetic relatedness; and it wasn’t Mendelian.  This led to the biometric-Mendelian debate.
Ronald Fisher, was actually a geneticist, who also invented p-value and Fisher exact test
Ronald Fisher (the one with the exact test) was also a geneticist.
Solved by assuming that phenotype often is an effect of several Mendelian genes.
Fisher: individual genes are mendelian, effects of genes additive
Hermann Muller 1920 (Nobel Prize for X-ray induced mutations).  PhD thesis not Mendelian trait, but truncate wing.  Wasn’t Mendelian.  Did genetic mapping.
Hermann Muller decided to use broken wing of fruit fly to study non-Mendelian diseases

Muller 1920 paper:  4 chromosomes in fly – 3 contain genes that influence the trait truncate wing.  Muller wrote about implications for human traits, like psychological traits.  Said that traits were going to be too complicated.  Said you could figure out by looking at population, but not looking at Mendelian inheritance in families.
Muller 1920 suggested that it needed to do study on a population.
Muller: Truncate wing - 3 genes influence effect of phenotype
Mullers thesis included the notion of surveying complex phenotypes in the population rather than families.
Muller: traits are too complex to observe in families, but can observe in population
characterization and catalogue  human seq  variation is a decade of work .. i.e international HapMap project
Another decade-long failure:  the candidate gene approach.  Instead, we need a genome-wide, unbiased approach.
Testing candidate genes was not successful. Only 10-20 successes.
779 GWA published for 148 traits
out come - 779 published GWA for 148 trails
For common diseases, GWA was needed
but "correlation does not imply causality"
There have been 779 genome-wide association studies (or regions/genes found?) for 148 traits, with p < 5x10^-8
"correlation does not imply causality" ....
But correlation does not imply causality.
The reasons of "Correlation does not imply causality": irreproducibility, lack of randomization, confounding, arrow of time.
If you can't randomize the experiment you can never prove causality as opposed to just being correlated to the underlying cause.
FF lag results in all these duplicate posts
a lot of efforts are on finding correlation between rare variation and diseases
rare variation is defined as has <5% in population
95% of  variations is already present in the database
Identified 50 regions that are associated with T2D
with in next few years ... the role of rare and less common variants will be characterized in a variety of diseases
next topic - can we obtains new insights into the basis of disease?
one example - sickle cell anemia
Sankaran et al Science 2008
Lettre et al PNAS 2008
Uda et al PNAS 2008
Crohn's disease: 15 years, no idea what was happening. Now many genes and 3 pathways are identified to be relevant.
96 loci explain ~25% of cholesterol levels
Lipid GWAS found 60 loci that are previous unknown. Some of the positives are drug targets already.
Global lipids consortium, forthcoming Nature paper (Nature paper is mentioned about 20 times !!!)
is there a way to automate validation/function determination?
prediction -- will prediction prove useful --this is depending on the clinical testing and the genetic test
prediction will be useful when there's a proven intervention
BRCA1/2 risk for cancer as an example
seq tech will increase the reach of genetic methods
mendelian fallacy - sub-populations are easily divisible in terms of risk
Prediction will only be useful if there is an intervention that you would not use without the prediction. Otherwise, you should use the intervention anyway.
Huntington will not be a representative example - for most diseases/people identified risk will be <<100% even with full genetic information
Cautionary tale - PSA prediction results in over-treatment, hasn't been shown that people live longer because of test
Very cautious about PSA - no improvements on the mortality but many operations performed.
genetics offers a path to discover the underlying biology of human diseases ; the great value will drive from pathophysiology and treatment

In 2005 we abandoned a monopolistic capillary electrophoresis; instead we have a couple and now 21 different technologies for sequencing. Resulted in a jump in rate of change of sequencing capacity

Close to the $1000 genome
(+ $100,000 interpretation cost?)  (he doesn't really think that)
Drmanac et al Science Jan 2010
Sidetrack: One friend said when he started his PhD it took 6 month to sequence a bacteria and 6-60 month to analyse it. Not it takes 6 minuted to sequence it and still 6-60 month to analyze it.
limitation is several hundreds nm in scale on chip (positive charge molecules on hydrophobic background
7% human genome is missing so far because of technical challenges
trio genomics information (father, mother, child) is increasing important in genomics research
From open acess Sequences to Bio-Fab

2nd-gen synthesis ($500 per 15 Mbp)

Next Gen synthesis: off chips $500 15Mbp
Tian et al 2004 Nature
The work started around 2003
personalgenomics.org
person genome 3M allele -> immunology + microbome -> trait

Have 16,000 volunteers for Personal Genome Project so far; 100,000 target.

They are rare but collective common at 10% level
Example of the Madsen family with two diseases.  Found causative allelles - 4 total (2 from each parent).
evidence.personalgenomics.org
Each time we find a scary allele in a person, it could be a sequencing error; it could be a problem with the literature.
found a dozen cases in the literature got allele sequence wrong
The oldest volunteer for PGP is 96.7 years old
Q: Are these genomes available ?
Circulating tumor, pathogen, fetal, and immune cells.
Microbe vs Immunome
If you want to look for a microorganism in a body, you can either look directly for the microbe, or look for the body's reaction.
immune test is to focus on response to exposure.
Sequencing after vaccination - response is maximum after 7 days
Generating human tissue from pluripotent stem cells
The Economist 20-May-2010 cover
Genome engineering
E.g., change the genetic code -- for resistance to pathogens, new amino acids, and something else.
You have to do this safely.
For $400M, Dupont made 27 changes to the 4.6 Mbp E. coli, to make a chemical.
Another application:  bio-petroleum from microbes.

Identify enzymes that synthesize alkane.  Many cyanobacteria made trace amounts; others made none.  Did genome sequence "subtraction" to find which genes were in the former.  Isolated & tested these genes.  Overproduced them; it worked.  Green chemistry.
Multiplex Automated Genome Engineering (MAGE)...
Church's own genome is available: http://www.personalgenomes.org/public...
So:  subtract my genome from Church's, then overproduce those genes --> TOTAL BRILLIANCE!
Example of freeing up a codon by changing those codons to a different one./
Is this not just the analysis. Not the sequence ? (or did I miss a link)
See the 'Datasets' header -> you can get 500k Affy data as well as exome
Metabolic engineering example.  Historically, you'd get obsessed with one step in the pathway and overproduce one enzyme.  But then you'd get product inhibition, or the product might be toxic.
Would be nice with a map to the reference genome as well, but guess that can be done
DNA Nanostructures: (DNA origami). Proposes a combination of DNA and proteins.
DNA nanostructures help solve structures of membrane proteins.

body: Special Public Lecture: Dr. Robert Weinberg - Cancer Stem Cells and the Evolution of Malignancy

comments.body: Shows picture of stages of cancer progression (ref Vogelstein, colon); poses the question of how metastasis occurs -- does this involve genetic or epigenetic changes?
Tan Ince cultured two kinds of normal human mammary epithelial cells.  He transformed them with oncogenes, resulting in different types of tumors.
Concludes that the nature of the normal cell of origin is a strong determinant of the phenotype of the primary tumor, and whether it metastasizes.  The playing field is tilted in the beginning.
Posits tumor-generating cells.
Self-renewing stem cells produce either more stem cells or transit amplifying cells which in turn lead to post-mitotic differentiated cells.  Only the self-renewing stem cell could seed a new tumor.
invasion-metastasis cascade
How do cancer cells acquire all of these capabilities (invasion, intravasastion, transport, metastasis...)  Are there addiitonal mutations required?  Is it epigenetic?
epithelial-mesenchymal transition -- cells on the perimeter of the tumor are mesenchymal.  This may be due to signals from the surrounding stroma.
There are probably 1000 proteins that shift in EMT.  Vaious transcription factors (TFs) induce EMTs.
EMT program highly complex and occurs normally during development.
It seems likely that most of the invasion-metastasis program can happen without need for additional mutations; rather use signaling from microenvironment.

P. Gupta transformed human primary melanocytes (pigmentation in the skin) with a cocktail of oncogenes.  Found that in contrast to transformed epithelial cells, there was much higher likelihood of metastasis.  Again, cell of origin is important in future behavior.
One TF, Slug, was found to enable melanoma metastasis.  (Even though the primary tumors grew a little faster.)
Another TF, FOXC2, when expressed in epithelial cells induces migration and invasion.  A subset of breast cancers have high levels of nuclear FOXC2, and these are more aggressive breast cancers.
Speculates that different networks of EMT-inducing factors might program metastasis in different cell types./
Stem cells identified by high CD44 and low CD24.  (CD's are markers on cell surface which can be assayed fairly easily.)
There are various ways to make cells acquire stem cell characteristics.
Mentions Kornelia Polyak.  There are stem-like cells in primary human breast samples.  The stem cell program in normal human mammary gland is coopted by cancer cells.
More proof that EMT creates stem cells.
Most current chemotherapies preferentially kill non-cancer-stem-cells.  The remaining stem cells can repopulate the tumor and are often more resistant to therapies.

Gupta & Onder tested CSCs and non_CSCs with a bunch of drugs.  There are some CSC-targeted agents (Salinomycin, Abamectin).  Of 16,000 compounds only about a dozen preferentially killed CSCs as opposed to non_CSCs.  Many were the other way round.
This probably won't be the "answer".  Christine Chaffer noticed that there were some floating cells in 2D cultured human mammary epithelial cells.  She grew these up; these look more like CSCs.
Interestingly, she found that non-CSCs could generate CSCs.
Hm, isn't this kind of pouring cold water on the excitement about CSCs as drug targets?  Or maybe you have to target both CSCs and non-CSCs simultaneously.
yup

Q:  cancer biologists like to study druggable genome.  But transcription factors seem most important.  A:  expression of TFs is controlled by cytoplasmic factors.  Might want to go after those.  Drugging the TF itself might be hard, but the signaling pathways might be more druggable.

Q:  has it been shown that change in the two forms of cadherins match the change in CD expression, and are these correlated with morphology?  A:  I showed that:  CD44 high cells shut down E-cadherin; they expression vimentin, and other mesenchymal markers.  I don't know whether CD44 is useful for non-mammary epithelial tissues.
Q:  So do normal non-SCs generate SCs?  A:  Yes.  Same differences as in cancer.
Spontaneous de-differentiation into SCs. Interesting phenomenon.

body: PLoS Session on How to Write a Good Paper

comments.body: Phil Bourne and Steven Brenner are presenting for the first hour, 10:45-11:40.
Having published good papers consistently counts for at least 50% of career advancement.

(Phil only published 2 papers in a 10-year period while he was leading the PDB.  That was a big mistake for traditional career path, but he wouldn't have done it any different way.  It was an issue when he came up for tenure.)
Other things that matter in an academic career:  Teching/mentoring, gratns, community service, good talks and networking.
Steven:  For a young scientist, papers matter even more.

Steven:  When I'm looking at a postdoc or junior faculty applicant, I look at where they trained, who their advisor was.  I look at what papers they were first author on.  Then, is there any paper that is a real standout and important.  Then, how many papers, and what is their nature.
Andrej:  what your rmentor says about you makes a lot of difference too.
Alan Turing - signal processing.  At AT&T he gave a talk that was never published; we attempted to reiterate this in a recent PLoS CB paper:  2007 3(10)e213.
Phil:  Work only on important problems.  Work with important people.  You have to figure out for yourself what is important.
Do this when you're young.

You need more than brains:  you need courage.  The system is not well geared for (especially) young people to take risks.  Risky papers are often rejected.  We're beginning to see evidence of how the review system fails.  The review system supports incremental work better than risky, outstanding work.

Take PLoS ONE.  PLoS ONE was intended to be a place to put work that may not be enormously innovative, but it is sound.  But what has happened is that it got a number of risky papers, some of which have turned out to be important, and highly cited.  So this journal that is supposed to be at the lower end of things, has a relative high impact factor.

Steven:  Examples.  Original paper where we wrote about the SCOP database.  Very highly cited.  Rejected by reviewers; my advisor battled the journal to get it published.  My arguably most important paper, identifying targets of nonsense-mediated decay, was rejected by three journals.  Most-cited paper in field of alternative splicing or nonsense-mediated decay.  Don't be discouraged!  If it's important, it will eventually be recognized.
Phil:  The PDB paper has been cited 10,000 times.  Noone has ever read it...
Luck favors the prepared mind.
Time management is critical.  The amount of time in the lab doesn't necessarily translate to productivity.  You don't get taught how to manage your time well.  Read books on time management.
Work from your heart.  If your heart is not in it, you won't succeed.  You need the passion to go the extra nine yards to do a great piece of work.
So all of that was prerequisite to writing a paper.  Now, how do you do it?
Start writing the paper on Day 1.
Draft paper helps focus the work, makes sure that you write it up; is easily shared with colleagues for feedback that can help you with the work itself.

Steven:  another reason to have it written up early in draft form -- I ignore "in preparation" on a resume.  If they say "in preparation, draft available", that makes an impact if I can see the draft.

Steven:  another reason to write the introduction early: "A month in the laboratory can save you an afternoon in the library."  Being forced to write the introduction might help you find previous work that will change what you do.
Phil:  If you hate writing, get over it.  If you do not write well, take classes.  Now.
? I wonder if they have suggestions for people who just don't have good command of English -- what about working with a writer, etc.?
Try to see your paper as the reviewer will see it.  Try to look at it "from a distance."
It might be motivating to you to realize that the paper is going to be your (scientific) legacy, long after you're gone.
Some ingredients of a good paper:  novlety, good coverage of the literature, good data, strong statistical support, clarity of presentation, thought-provoking discussion.
Look at the scope statements of the journal you're thinking of submitting to.
Don't rely on your PI to tell you the novelty of the work - figure it out for yourself.
In discussion, guide people to build on the work.
DON'T try and prove that you are smart.
Avoid the kitchen sink syndrome = putting too much that is not relevant into the paper.

Maintain a good bibliographic database (EndNote, RefWorks, etc.).  Consult a citation index (ISI, Google Scholar); consider using that to annotate your database entries.  Use a tool like Mendeley to store annotations.
(Mendeley is a way of annotating PDFs; you can share annotations.)  Explore social bookmarking to find out what others have been saying about papers.
Q: how important is the citation index of a paper?  A:  not important.  What matters is how good and relevant the paper is.
In 2000, Phil wrote a paper on alternative views of looking at protein space.  For 5 years, noone cited it.  But then it became a hot topic and citations started to pick up.

Steven:  There is a tendency to have a winner-take-all approach.  Everyone will cite one paper, even if there is a more relevant paper.  It's important to go out and find out which papers really are most relevant.

Steven:  Have your whole lab get together and pick one program to store your data.  Even if it's not the best program, being able to share the tool is really valuable.  Phil:  we lack good project management tools that map to the scientific endeavor to allow us to share and maintain output from the lab.  Come talk to me about developing a company around this...
Phil:  Have colleagues critique your paper.
Become a reviewer early.  Shadow more senior people in reviewing.  Look at the other reviews of the paper.
Approach program committees of conferences.

Hold journal clubs.  Identify good and bad papers in journal club and elsewhere and study tehm.  A good paper will likely tell a story and be enjoyable to read and follow.  It's pitched at the right level for the intended audience.
Acknowledge the people who submitted the review.

Q:  will the program committees and journals accept volunteer reviewers, or do you have to be asked?  Steven:  There are two ways this can work.  First, a PI can invite a student of theirs to help review it.  Second, if I can't review it myself, I can recommend someone in my lab to do the reviewer completely themselves.  The editor then can choose whether to use this student/postdoc reviewer.

Choose the journal wisely.  Do you read that journal?  Do you cite it?  Is it a top-notch editorial board?  Does it have highly accessed papers?  What is the rejection rate?  What is the average time to publication?  (Find out by talking to people who have published in that journal.)  Is it indexed in PubMed?
And, most importantly, does the scope match your work??
Use the presubmission inquiry if the journal has one; it helps in determining scope.

Mark:  what emphasis to place on how highly cited the journal is?  Phil:  I don't care anymore at my point in my career.  This is my personal opinion.  The review process is quite broken.  But others judge job candidates by this.  What do you think?
Mark: shouldn't think about impact factors.
Phil:  Other communities do not have a review process, but a moderation.  Then it is how much it is accessed by the community is the judgment of its worth.

Steven:  You need to think about who will be evaluating you in your career.  Traditionalists will care about which journal.  If you are looking for a job right out of post-doc, won't have time to have gotten citations on the paper, so which journal matters more.  It helps to have letters of reference that describe the importance of the work.
It helps to understand the editorial process.
Know that the best scientists get rejected and/or have to make major revisions.

Post-review phase.  Again, "get over it".  Buckle down and do the work.  Don't be defensive.  Address every aspect of the reviewers' concern.  It's fine to disagree with a reviewer, but have the conversation, don't shy away from it.  Make it clear how your revision addresses the reviewers' points.
Examples of a good paper and bad paper...  No time to do this...

Steven:  Bear in mind that the reason we do science is to create new knowledge and contribute that to the body of scientific knowledge.  You do that through your papers.  So papers must be an effective conduit.

Steven:  Ability to communicate is key.  Most of us are not great writers.  You need to figure out what works for you.  Team writing can be very effective.  Example: one student had to talk it through first.
Share it with colleagues before sending it out for review.
Make sure you make it easy for the reviewers.  Example:  when you make a revision, make it clear what you changed.

Figures.  When people flip through a paper, they usually look at the figures first.  You should invest major effort in getting the figures perfect.  You might revise a figure 100 times.  I have people in my lab take a course in the visual presentation of information.
Steven (still): it's important to make sure that you are right.  If you have 10 papers and one has a major flaw, that can be devastating.
Surya Saha - just finished PhD and starting post-doc.  Has these questions from first-time authors
(We are going into the second half of the workshop, with a panel of 7 people)
Surya:  what happens inside the editorial process of a journal?
Nils Gehlenberg - student.  Pros and cons for new authors of supporting alternative publishing and evaluation models.
Article metrics.  At yesterday's future of scientific publishing - I can influence citing in blogs and social networking sites.  Should I go out and market my papers?
What about publishing that are not papers - like data, or software tools?  Will that look good on my resume?
Mark Gerstein (experienced author):  Scientific publishing in the future.

We are seeing a distinction between databases and journals getting blurred.  People are approaching reading like databases -- you query for an article.  Also, people read database entries, e.g., to find out about gene function.

It's hard to fit everything into conventional journal articles or biological databases.  Why are people citing SCOP so much (for example)?  Are they *reading* it?  Or is it associated with a piece of code or database that they're using?  The latter, often.
People cite a paper not because they read it but because they saw an easy-to-read summary or someone cited it in a lecture that they saw.

Mark's view:  We can update scientific publishing; make it more multi-tiered, more compatible with the digital world.  I advocate a structured digital paper.  It's not a single narrative, but a set of streams of information - some computer-readable and structured; one or more stream for the human reader.
You do this not as separate from the paper publishing, but as part of publishing the paper.
Structured abstract.  Structured digital table.  (Are examples)
Chris Sander speaks next.
We have a project:  the Factoid Project.
Factoid Project: require authors to submit basic facts they've derived to a database.
Scientific publishing needs to be revolutionalized.
We need to take away power from reviewers and editors.
We should engage in marketing our papers (though prefer a different term)
We should change how papers are evaluated by potential employers and tenure committees and so on.

Talks about figures with (A), (B), (C), and having to find the letter in the caption.  Figure captions are hard to read and understand.  In Time Magazine, you won’t see those.  Appeal: make figures an integrated information panel.
Let’s put together a small working group; write up an opinion piece, send it to journals and ask for a change. I’ll help.
Chris proposes another working group about assessing a paper’s impact and the author’s contribution.
Chris: Doesn't like PLoS Computational Biology because of the goal of increasing the rejection rate to improve impact factor.  Optimize scientific contribution not rejection rate.

Chris:  How your papers get advertised.  You can promote your own work.  Don't just rely on the editors.  Don't just rely on the reviewers.  Don't rely on the paper coming out and someone maybe reading it and citing it.  Coming here and doing posters.
Gary Benson:  Professor at BU; editor at NAR.  Edits web server issue, an annual special issue.
I like papers, says Gary.  I like looking at figures.  I like when people put a lot of effort into organizing their thoughts.  I like it when people use examples in their papers.
narwbsrv@bu.edu if you're interested to submit a paper.

In Comp Bio, people make predictions about something.  It's easy to make predictions; it's not easy to validate them.  At NAR, we have a strict policy that you have to show considerable evidence of validation, with data that was not used to develop the model you're presenting.
Pitfalls for journal submission.

Prior publication:  Arxiv is an archive; that is not considered (by NAR) a citable publication, so it's OK - would not exclude your article for that reason.  On the other hand, we saw a paper previously appearing in PLoS Currents -- and we do consider that a prior publication because cited in PubMed.
Conference submissions are prior publications in some cases.  Conference proceedings can have fairly large papers, and are usually citable.

Open access:  this is a journal's way to compete with online repositories.  It's a way to make your paper free to everyone.  All publishing should be like that - but it costs money.  Authors have to pay usually, for open access.

The review process at NAR:  Senior editor evaluates for meeting scope.  Pass it on; next editor again considers scope.  If that passes, then get reviewers.  Authors are asked to suggest reviewers.  If you propose reviewers, pick people who are not your friends but are knowledgeable in the area.
We pick 2 reviewers.  You appreciate as an editor getting suggestions for reviewers.  I usually respond positively to volunteer reviewers.

Reviews usually take 2 weeks at our journal.  Some are good, some are not.  You want more than a paragraph!  Then the editors try to make a judgment based on those reviews.  If there is disagreement the editors will seek a third review, and this can take additional time.  The editor usually informs the author of this delay.
We try to have a 30-day turnaround time.  Then if the reviews are positive, you get a chance to modify your paper, and our goal is 60 days.
Be non-confrontational in your letter responding to the reviewers that accompanies your revised manuscript.  This is a dialogue between you and the reviewers, monitored by the editor.
End of Gary's introduction
Andrej Sali speaks next.
Presubmission inquiry - the editor is looking both at scope and at quality.  It's important to put effort into this.

Suggested reviewer lists:  I found through experience that it is difficult for authors to predict which reviewers will be fair or supportive, or negative.  You may think someone is your friend, but they are not always your friend.  Don't put too much attention onto who you think is your friend.
Phil will put his slides on the PLoS CB website; Andrej thinks that’s great, and he’ll be requiring people in his group to go through them.
Try to satisfy reviewers.  Why not?  Obviously, you want to do what you think is right scientifically, so do not compromise that.

Collect common wisdom within your lab about writing.  In my (Andrej's) group:  definitely start with written document on Day 1.  Outline the manuscript before you start the project.  Keep it up to date as the process goes on.  Keep in mind the key idea - why should people read it?  Summarize that in the title.  No more than 2-3 sentences on the main message.
On to Alfonso Valencia, editor of Bioinformatics.

What to publish: your work.
Where to publish: Bioinformatics, obviously.  :-).  
When to publish: not before my holidays.
There is both opportunity and risk.  Consider the music industry:  the web has had a huge impact; musicians aren't sure how they are going to survive.  Newspapers too - huge changes.
The web affects not only science reporting but science production.
People who have already built a solid scientific reputation can afford to try out and champion new modes of publishing.  Young scientists have to be much more careful so as not to harm their career.
Not all papers are equal.  Application notes are different than scientific papers are different than discovery notes.
It's more important to be able to build on a paper than to reproduce the paper.  A good paper enables more research.
Publications are an essential instrument not only for knowledge distribution but also as a tool for organizational decision-making:  evaluation of institutions, grants, fellowships, positions.
Before replacing impact factors, think: with what?
You don't have to do all that the referees/editors ask for, even if it means your paper gets rejected.  Use your own scientific judgment.
Build on others' work.  Quote them fairly and with respect.
Discuss your results in meetings and with colleagues before publishing.  In bioinformatics, the risk of being scooped is minimal.  The benefit of sharing and getting feedback is enormous.
bb, thanks for the comprehensive coverage!
You're welcome! :-)
Thanks!
A big thank you for the coverage bb
yes, just great, bb!

feed_description:
International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Molecular Biology
The talk specific feeds will be created each day shortly before the start of the first presentation. Find talk specific blogs by searching here for the title of the talk or the talk identifier as given in the program (like HL03 for the 3rd Highlight paper). The feeds can also be accessed on the conference pages in the according sections: SIGs, Keynotes, LBR, Proceedings, Tech Track and Highlights.

Happy blogging !!
